Theory of emotions and economic analysis:
a review1
Emmanuel Petit*
Since Elster’s seminal review [1998], an abundant literature has revealed the growing interest of economists in the question of emotions.

The introduction of emotion into economic analysis has been carried out essentially from a psychological and neurological conception of emotion. Developing a richer and more complete economy of emotions makes it necessary to also draw on other approaches to emotion, notably from sociology, anthropology, history and philosophy.

The aim of this article is to contribute to enriching the work of economists in this field by proposing a multidisciplinary state of the art that synthesizes the knowledge derived from the theory of emotions. The first step is to identify the major stages in the construction of this theory and to extract the essential properties of emotions. The aim is then to illustrate how this knowledge has been mobilized in economic analysis, taking into account the diversity of approaches characteristic of the discipline.

As in many academic disciplines, economists have accompanied what historians have called the “emotional turn” (Plamper [2010]), an extraordinary craze born in the mid-1990s for the study of emotions.

In economics, emotions are today mainly mobilized and studied in an experimental framework and then introduced into behavioral models in order to improve existing models of human behavior. The “economics of emotions” (Petit [2015]) has made it possible to “revisit” the model of perfect rationality (Elster [1996], Kahneman

[2012], Rolls [2019]), has introduced a plurality of social and/or moral motivations (Jourdheuil and Petit [2015]) and has led to new methods of intervention by public authorities such asand emotional paternalism (Schultz et al. As suggested by Elster [1998], this conception made it possible (i) to disturb emotion in categories that could be easily mobilized by economists, (ii) to give it a functional (multi-component) definition particularly adapted to the methodological individualism practiced in experimental and behavioral economics and above all (iii) to provide precise and effective instruments for measuring and inducing emotions.

The introduction of emotion into economic analysis was carried out
essentially from a psychological and neurological conception of emotion.

As suggested by Elster [1998], this conception made it possible (i) to disturb emotion in categories that could be easily mobilized by economists, (ii) to give it a functional (multi-component) definition particularly adapted to the methodological individualism practiced in experimental and behavioral economics and above all (iii) to provide precise and effective instruments for measuring and inducing emotions.

The theory of emotions that was gradually established during the 20th century, however, covers a much broader field of analysis than that taken into account by psychology and neuroscience. Other disciplines – such as sociology, philosophy, anthropology, history and literature – have also constructed an elaborate and fruitful theory of emotions. Recent work on the theory of emotions also shows that there is now a convergence between approaches that were once opposed and considered incompatible (biology vs. anthropology, psychology vs. sociology).

Recent work on the theory of emotions also shows that there is now a convergence between approaches that were once opposed and considered incompatible (biology vs. anthropology, psychology vs. sociology).

Developing a richer and more complete “economy of emotions” makes it necessary to know and draw on the different approaches to emotion, without limiting ourselves to the sole conception of psychology and/or neurology.

The aim of this review is therefore to contribute to enriching the work of economists in this field by proposing a multidisciplinary state of the art that synthesizes the knowledge derived from the theory of emotions.
First of all, it is a question of identifying the main stages in the construction of this theory and extracting the essential properties of emotions (2).

The aim then is to illustrate – as extensively as possible but without claiming to be exhaustive – how this knowledge has been used in economic analysis, taking into account the diversity of approaches characteristic of the discipline (3). We will conclude this review of the literature on the theory and economics of emotions by discussing and identifying the most fruitful and promising areas of research for economists (4).

The science of emotions: expression, behavior, and social construction It is possible to juxtapose two major concepts in contemporary scientific approaches to emotion23. First of all, we find the authors who consider that emotions correspond to an objective empirical reality that can be defined, analyzed, evaluated and broken down. Schematically, the proponents of this first trend are located more in the life sciences, in the medical sciences or in experimental sciences such as psychology or neuroscience.

Within this first trend, there are, on the one hand, those who give primacy to the bodily, physiological, biological dimension of emotion (2.1) and, on the other hand, those who, by relativizing the scope of the body, reveal the importance of cognition and psychological processes (2.2).

The physiological and biological dimension
of emotion
The first scientific approach to the theory of emotions emphasizes
the physiological, biological and universal dimension of emotion. It can be summarized by saying that emotion is located in the body and that consequently emotions can be produced, expressed and recognized by any human, regardless of their culture.

It can be summarized by saying that emotion is located in the body and that consequently emotions can be produced, expressed and recognized by any human, regardless of their culture. An emotion such as fear, for example, would have this universal, innate, natural dimension, which is manifested by certain facial expressions (tensing) or body expressions (trembling, cold sweat, palpitations, etc.).

For a very long time, many thinkers have sought to locate

In Darwin's naturalist approach [1872], emotions are conceived as current vestiges of the distant origins of the human species. The interest of Darwin's work [1872] is to codify on an empirical level a rigorous method of evaluating facial expressions that will be explored in more depth by psychologists and biologists a century later (Ekman and Davidson [1994], Plutchik [1984]) and then used by modern facial recognition technologies (in particular for so-called "basic" or "universal" emotions (Ekman [1999]). James-Lange's thesis is revolutionary as well as counter-intuitive. These authors put forward the idea that physiological and bodily changes, as well as the behaviors associated with them, are not the "consequence" of emotion (as common sense and the classical approaches of the time claim) but the "cause".

These authors put forward the idea that physiological and bodily changes, as well as the behaviors associated with them, are not the "consequence" of emotion (as common sense and the classical approaches of the time claim) but the "cause". According to this conception, becoming aware of these physiological changes constitutes emotion in itself. For example, when we realize that we are in danger, this perception triggers a set of bodily responses and it is our awareness of these responses that constitutes fear.

quantitative tools and the Official Journals of 1907 in order to document the way in which emotion 
evolves – in the debates and in the reactions of the Assembly – during this crisis.

We suggest that when the theme of 
wine is addressed in the Chamber, the deputies use a more emotive rhetoric and that the audience reacts more. However, more than the theme of wine, it is 
the social consequences of the crisis (the demonstrations, the mutiny, etc.) 
that explain this recourse to emotion.

Summary
Our quantitative analysis reveals that 
the fervour induced by the wine crisis 
is reflected in the debates in the Chamber 
by a significant increase in emotional occurrences. During this period, 
MPs and members of the Government were subjected to strong 
emotions that they expressed or relayed. What preoccupied 
MPs were mainly the social consequences 
induced by the crisis at the time of the June 1907 riots.
